data.title: 2022 Video Game Awards Season - Tracking and Discussion Thread (New!: Categories and Genre Winners added) News - Entertainment
data.meta_description:

data.text:
Another year, another award season. Last year was a very spread out year with many games having a shot at the title. The overall winner ended being the co-op darling It Takes Two by Hazelight; taking the lead with just 84 awards total.

This year will pit the critically acclaimed and commercially successful Elden Ring against the highly anticipated and also critically acclaimed sequel of 2018's overall GOTY, God of War Ragnarok. Other potential candidates include the indies darlings such Neon White and Sam Barlow's Immortality, Nintendo's big threequels such as Xenoblade Chronicles 3 and Bayonetta 3 and PS Studios' Horizon Forbidden West and Gran Turismo 7. There's also some potential late candidates such Obsidian's Pentiment and The Callisto Protocol. Will we have surprise winners or the usual title match between the 2 top rated games?

In previous years we have used both GOTYblog; the pioneer of the GOTY tallies/rules (as far as we can tell) and gameawards.net; which took on the mantle post 2019, they later added new rules to legitimize the tallies and went as far as to the tallies for previous years, increasing the total for many games. Unfortunately due to various reasons including inactivity, these sites are not longer being used as source for GOTY tallies.

Instead we are tackling this year's GOTY tally on our own with the help from various ERA users and other onlookers. It must be said that previous sites were already using these threads as a source for any findings, so we are confident that we'll be able to make it work as well and as fair as they would have.

In the meantime, User a0mineda1k1 has created a GOTY tracking site (work in progress) which is in process of backing up previous years from the previous sites and will update this year's tally based on the findings on this thread.

Until further notice, the rules for eligibility will remain mostly the same from those created by GOTYBlog and gameawards.net. Of course, if there's any rules worth questioning or changing, feel free to bring them up for discussion.

Lastly feel free to help out in finding and posting any awards you find. A lot of sites come and go and it will definitely help keep the tallies as accurate as possible. I have a feeling a lot of them will be counted for this year for two obvious candidates.

Visit the GOTY Awards Tracker website by a0mineda1k1 for more details and previous GOTY winners [work in progress]:

Game of the Year - Award Tracker

Here you can see the awards for the best game of the year according to different media

Special Thanks to all the contributors who make all of this happen!

Guidelines & Rules

Originally Created by gotyblog & gameawards.net

Updated - 12/11/2023

Any console, PC, handheld or mobile video game is included, provided that it is named the overall Game of the Year (GOTY) from an eligible media outlet.

"Expansions"/DLC, whether standalone or add-ons, to otherwise eligible titles are included.

All "Remake" versions are included from 2019 onward.

Votes awarded to non-remastered or non-remade "ports" (i.e. a game re-released on new platforms in largely the same state) will be counted toward the totals in the year of the title's initial U.S. release date.

To be eligible, the awarded title needs to have been released in the country of the media outlet. For media outlet critics, the title needs to have been released for review to critics before the publication of the award. For "readers' choice" votes, the title needs to have been released to the public before voting begins.

"Media outlets" include websites, magazines, newspapers, radio and TV broadcasts, podcasts, industry ceremonies, and online entertainment companies.

Media Outlets must be active for more than a year and consistently produce gaming related articles, videos or content.

Award results from the outlets may be announced on any platform, including social media.

If a previously ineligible outlet provides more than a year of content, both their current and previous winners will be eligible as long as they still meet the required criteria below.

Outlets with ties of toxic behavior, discriminatory articles or considered as a bad influence to the gaming community are not eligible.

Outlets that are suspected to have AI created content are not eligible.

Outlets that appears to be predominantly operated by a single individual/staff member will be not be eligible.

There must be more than 1 working staff who consistently contribute to the outlet, specifically the outlet's gaming related content.

At least two staff members need to be part of the award selection process.

If the Outlet's winner is posted by an individual rather than multiple staff members, it can still be eligible as long as they indicate that it is not a personal/individual list.

Student-operated newspapers are counted provided that they are from a college or university and they regularly write content for the majority of the year and they meet all of the other criteria.

User community sites that allow free-email or anonymous registration are not eligible.

Outlets with an overly restrictive scope—focusing on a particular region, genre, or concept to the exclusion of most games—are not eligible.

To avoid platform bias, votes from media outlets that are exclusively focused on a single platform or family of platforms (PlayStation, Xbox, PC, etc.) are not eligible.

Only overall GOTY awards are eligible. Individual genre, platform and technical achievement awards do not count toward a title's total GOTY awards.

An outlet's 'overall GOTY' is the single title to which they give their highest award of the year, except in the case of a tie/draw vote.

If a tie occurs, then all winners will be counted.

The number of titles awarded needs to be fewer than the number of staff on the voting team. For example, an outlet with three voting staff members cannot simply name each of their separate, personal favorites as the three different winners and call that a draw; if those three staff members have two titles tie as the result of a points system however, those two titles would be eligible. A maximum of three titles will be accepted as a points-based draw.

"Best of the year" lists are counted as a media outlet's overall GOTY if the top choice is clearly communicated and the site does not have a separate formal GOTY award selection.

Inherently excluding any category of games from the GOTY awards, including indie titles, means that the main award is not actually an "overall" award, as it is not open to nominating games overall but only a certain subset of them.

A site can separately recognize any categories that they wish ("best AAA games," "best indies," etc), and they do not need to nominate all types of games every year, but their highest award needs to at least, in principle, be open to games from all categories.

If a site has strict rules, such as excluding DLCs and Remakes, they will be counted just as long as it within reason.

Retrospective awards are only accepted for years that the media outlet actually existed, produced regular content for more than half of the year, and did not originally give out an award for the year in question.

"Retrospective" refers to any awards not given during the original year or subsequent year of the award title (for example, giving an award for 2016 in 2018 or later.)
